name: Rocky Creek (Mt Buffalo)
description:
With A large amount of rock scrambling, and a lot less abseiling than other Buffalo canyons this is more of a creekside bushwalking trip with a couple of abseils than a canyoning trip.

Approach

Two options: 1) follow the abandoned fire trail up the spur from the lower carpark. This was graded in the late 2010s but has been taken over by regrowth. There is no scrambling required but at times has some denser regrowth. This does involve almost 800m of elevation gain. 2) With a 78km shuttle the easier option is to park at the reservoir carpark and follow the maintained Rocky Creek firetrail to the campsite.

Either option, you will need to drop off the trail about 300m west of the bridge over rocky creek, near where the track turns North over the implied knoll.

Descent

Scramble down the frosty Rocky Creek, wading at times. Most waterfalls can be climbed around, but three have significant exposure and are better abseiled. The longest abseil is 20m.

Exit

The last scrambling is at the junction to Bunyip Creek after which it's just a matter of following the stream down. About 900m before the road there is an abandoned mining race on the river right, which can be followed back to the approach track (if you climbed up the steep western face)
